lt is not clear what the words ‘quod et praetores postea secuti esse videntur’ refer to: perhaps to the bononun possessio intestati, but more probably to the bonomm possessio contra tabulas immediately before the rescript of M. Aurelius, p. 247 supr.

§¹1. The ‘adminiculum’ referred to is the querella inofficiosi testa- menti, for which see Tit 18 inf.

Bonorum possessio contra tabulas, referred to in this Title, was granted, not only to pretermitted liberi, but also, under certain circum- stances, (a) to the parens manumissor against the will of his emancipated son, Bk. i. 12. 6 supr, Dig.37.12; (b) to a patron aud his agnatic de· scendants against the will of bis libertus (Blr. iii. 7 inf.) or liberta (Gaius i. 192, ii 122, iii. 43-4); (c) to a patroness against the will of her liberta, Gaius iii. 52.

When granted to a descendant who was not disinherited by the ancestor in the form required by the edict, its effect, if the praeteritus was a suus, was practically to substitute intestate succession for succes- sion under the will, if not, its effect will appear more clearly frorn the following :— ,
